nodes.bodyText: That's interesting, asserting on the data provider?
Not that it matters, but you could throw an UncheckedIOException.
In Presto, the naming convention is to have Test as the class name prefix (except for test base classes).
bump; you fixed the name in the second commit

avoid IO in test init / cinit (surefire is notorious about misreporting errors during this phase)
use @BeforeClass instead (here this would need to be done in createQueryRunner method actually)
move ImmutableList.of( to next line
i strongly prefer using default @DataProvider name (ie method name). One name less.

In theory format may mask problems. Just SELECT * would be better.
Since you have expected  values at hand, "VALUES " doesn't really help you (joiner, ,etc). you can computeActual and you should get BigDecimals in return
irrelevant, so you use default (new SecurityConfig().getSecuritySystem())
Default throws exception during table drop: java.lang.RuntimeException: Access Denied: Cannot drop table tpch.decimal_4_2_fle_rescale
relevant?
what does "order" stand for here?
is it suitable also for scale!=0 ?
yes, it's how the decimal is represented in parquet (decimals got converted to longs)
private
importing static methods from it so protected
nit: we most often place createQueryRunner above the tests
why change here?
Decimal(3, 0) cannot keep -1000..1000 ints
ok, make it separate commit
why change here?
Decimal(3, 0) cannot keep -1000..1000 ints
ok, make it separate commit
the change here is more that removing assertThatThrownBy. Why?
Because now values are scaled (in the test the readValues were dummy) so we are actually testing a round-trip of read-write valeus
the change here is more that removing assertThatThrownBy. Why?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -910,15 +909,13 @@ public void testDecimalBackedByFixedLenByteArray()
 
     @Test
     public void testParquetLongDecimalWriteToPrestoDecimalWithNonMatchingScale()
+            throws Exception
     {
-        assertThatThrownBy(() ->
-                tester.testRoundTrip(
-                        new JavaHiveDecimalObjectInspector(new DecimalTypeInfo(38, 10)),
-                        ImmutableList.of(HiveDecimal.create(0)),
-                        ImmutableList.of(new SqlDecimal(BigInteger.ZERO, 38, 10)),
-                        createDecimalType(38, 9)))
-                .hasMessage("Presto decimal column type has different scale (9) than Parquet decimal column (10)")

nodes.bodyText: Serializing 0 in every scale/precision yields zero so I've changed to values that actually got rescaled

-                .hasMessage("Presto decimal column type has different scale (9) than Parquet decimal column (10)")

nodes.bodyText: why change here?
make it separate commit
redundant
Would be good to add a javadoc to each method explaining what test covers, perhaps along with an example. Terms "rescaled", "rounded", "roundable" are not obvious.
belongs to prev commit
belongs to prev commit
belongs to prev commit; however, i suggested to change thus to computeActual anyway
belongs to prev commit
belongs to prev commit

This should not happen (bug in the code), so now need to PrestoException.
throw new IllegalArgumentException("Unsupported type: " + type);
bump
nit: i'd inline these variables
thoughts?
Consider it done ;)

private (here & below)
REAL, DOUBLE and DECIMAL are also number types
protected

no need for if here, since you already validate it's either decimal or "number"
(otherwise there should be else branch that throws something)
move into if branch where it's used

"scaledValue" is a wrong name, because it's "unscaled value in presto decimal type", right?
"convertedValue"?

I don't like fake information, because this is error prone.
Fortunately, the result of this assignment is never used.
You can restructure the code slightly and remove the fake.

Remove empty @param lines, they don't add any value
here & below

This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                 * if Parquet decimal value could be rescaled into Presto decimal without loosing most and least significant digits.
          
          
            
                 * if Parquet decimal value could be rescaled into Presto decimal without losing most and least significant digits.

String tableName arg is unnecessary, because each test can use a random (or string.format-created) table name.
This serves the purpose of identifying tests runs though. It will be satisfied, if you move int precision, int scale as initial args, then forceFixedLengthArray.

This isn't going to be reusable, because this generates the test cases matching exactly testReadingMatchingPrecision test specification, so

move right under the test method
consider naming it testReadingMatchingPrecisionDataProvider
collect to list + .toArray = .toArray(BigDecimal[]::new)
remove
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -112,6 +113,86 @@ public void testReadingMatchingPrecision(String tableName, boolean forceFixedLen
         dropTable(tableName);
     }
 
+    /**
+     * Tests if Parquet decimal with given precision and scale can be read into Presto decimal with different precision and scale
+     * if Parquet decimal value could be rescaled into Presto decimal without loosing most and least significant digits.
+     *
+     * @param tableName
+     * @param forceFixedLengthArray
+     * @param precision
+     * @param scale
+     * @param values
+     * @param schemaPrecision
+     * @param schemaScale
+     * @param expected

+    @DataProvider
+    public Object[][] differentFittingRescaling()
+    {

+                {"decimal_10_2_rescale", false,
+                        10, 2,
+                        ImmutableList.of("10.01", "10", "1.23", maximumValue(10, 2), minimumValue(10, 2)),
+                        12, 4,

nodes.bodyText:
Why is this failure? is it because maximumValue(10, 2) doesn't fit? Then remove other test values, they are misleading. Maybe also use explicit value "99999999.99" instead if maximumValue, to make things more explicit.
Same for other negative test cases.
